title: Project Constraints
description: Master the interplay between scope, time, cost, quality, risk, and resources.
objectives: Apply the triple constraint model (scope, time, cost)

screens.headline: The Investor Wants It Earlier

dialogue.text: Alex, I need the restaurant open 2 months earlier to catch the holiday season. Same budget, same scope. Just make it happen faster.

screens.learningHook: When one constraint changes, others must adjust. You can't compress time without impacting cost, scope, or quality. Understanding trade-offs is essential for PM success.

screens.title: Constraint Trade-off Decisions
screens.instructions: Ava wants the restaurant 2 months earlier. Analyze the trade-offs and recommend a solution.

original.scope: Full restaurant with patio, private dining room, full kitchen

questions.question: Can Alex deliver the same scope in 4 months at the same $850K budget?

options.text: Yes—just work harder and faster
No—something must change (cost, scope, or quality will be impacted)
Yes—if Alex uses better project management techniques
It depends on team motivation

questions.question: What are Alex's options to meet the 4-month deadline? Select ALL valid trade-offs.

options.text: Increase budget (pay for overtime, more workers, expedited materials)
Reduce scope (eliminate patio, simplify private dining room)
Accept lower quality (skip inspections, use cheaper materials)
Tell Ava 'no' without offering alternatives
Hope for the best and commit to 4 months

questions.question: Rank these trade-off options from BEST to WORST for Savory & Co.'s situation:

options.text: Increase budget by $150K for expedited construction
Reduce scope: Open without patio (add later)
Accept lower quality materials to save time

questions.feedback: Reducing scope (patio later) preserves quality and budget. Budget increase is viable if Ava approves. Quality compromise risks long-term reputation.

questions.question: Write a 50-100 word recommendation to present to Ava. Include: the constraint reality, your recommended trade-off, and the benefit.
successCriteria: Frames benefit to Ava (ROI, holiday season)

content.definition: Every project is bounded by three interconnected constraints: Scope, Time, and Cost.
content.insight: Change one corner, and the others must adjust—or quality suffers.
content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Ed evolved this to Performance Domains, but the constraint concept remains fundamental

content.rule: You CANNOT optimize all three simultaneously. Trade-offs are inevitable.

content.position: Quality sits at the CENTER of the triangle—impacted by how you balance the three constraints.

examples.trade-off: Rush time + fixed budget + same scope
Add scope + fixed time + fixed budget
Cut budget + same scope + same time

content.insight: Quality is often the 'hidden victim' of poor constraint management.

beyondTriple.description: Uncertainty that could impact other constraints

content.modernView: PMBOK 7th Ed expands beyond triple constraint to value delivery and outcomes.
content.insight: Successful PMs manage ALL constraints holistically, not just scope/time/cost.

framework.step1: Acknowledge the request ('I understand you want to open 2 months early')
framework.step2: Explain the constraint reality ('Given our current budget and scope, this creates a trade-off')
framework.step3: Present options ('We can: increase budget, reduce scope, or accept quality risk')
framework.step4: Recommend one ('I recommend reducing scope by deferring the patio')
framework.step5: Explain the benefit ('This preserves quality and budget while meeting your holiday goal')

content.insight: Great PMs don't just say 'no'—they present OPTIONS that balance stakeholder needs with project reality.

screens.title: New Constraint Pressure
screens.context: Elena (CFO) says the budget must be cut by $100K due to economic conditions. Same timeline, same scope.

questions.question: What are Alex's options to handle the $100K budget cut?

options.text: Extend timeline (slower pace, smaller team)
Reduce scope (eliminate features)
Use cheaper materials (quality trade-off)
Ignore the cut and continue as planned

questions.question: If Alex chooses to extend the timeline by 1 month to absorb the budget cut, what happens?

options.text: Quality automatically improves
Ava may be unhappy (misses holiday season)
Scope automatically increases
Nothing changes except the end date

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: Project constraints are interconnected. When one changes, others must adjust or quality suffers.
takeaways: Triple Constraint: Scope, Time, Cost are interconnected
Quality sits at the center—impacted by all three
You CANNOT optimize all constraints simultaneously—trade-offs are inevitable
Extended constraints: Risk, Resources, Customer Satisfaction
When stakeholders request changes, present OPTIONS with trade-offs
Great PMs don't say 'no'—they say 'yes, if...' with clear impacts

artifacts.title: Constraint Communication Framework
artifacts.description: How to present options to stakeholders

characterClosing.text: Alex, I appreciate you not just saying 'no.' Opening without the patio and adding it later makes sense. You protected quality while meeting my timeline. That's professional.
